title: 3 Simple Ways to Transfer a Drawing to Canvas

steps.title: Print out or make a copy of the drawing you want to transfer.
steps.content: Print out or make a copy of the drawing you want to transfer. You will be covering the back of the drawing in charcoal to transfer it to the canvas. Copy it so you don’t have to do this to the original copy of the drawing. Print it out or copy it with a scanner onto a new sheet of paper. [1] X Research source You can also change the size of the drawing when you do this if you want it to fit on a smaller or larger canvas. Use the scale feature when printing to have the computer automatically resize it to fit the paper size you’re printing on. If you don’t have access to a printer, pull up a scan of your drawing or image on your computer’s screen, sized as you want it to transfer. Trace it by placing tracing paper, or thin regular paper, over the screen and using a pencil. This works best in a dark room.

steps.title: Cover the back of the paper in charcoal wherever there are lines.
steps.content: Cover the back of the paper in charcoal wherever there are lines. Place the copy of the drawing face down (AKA, drawing-side down) on a hard, flat work surface. Use a soft charcoal stick to rub over the back of the paper where the drawing’s lines are. Use side-to-side motions with the side of the charcoal stick to cover more area at once. [2] X Research source You don’t have to cover the paper completely, just where the drawing is on the other side, says Medford. [3] X Expert Source Kelly Medford Professional Artist Expert Interview. 26 March 2021. If there are any large spaces without lines on the drawing, hold the copy up to a window and mark those areas with a pencil before you start coloring the paper with charcoal. This way, you can more easily avoid those spots to save time and charcoal. If you don't have a lot of charcoal, just retrace over the lines of the main shapes instead of shading the page entirely. Shake off any loose charcoal dust onto a piece of paper and toss it afterward. You could also pour the dust straight into a trash bin if there’s one nearby. Just be careful not to spill any charcoal on a carpet or anywhere that it might stain.

steps.title: Tape the drawing to the canvas, charcoal-side down, with masking tape.
steps.content: Tape the drawing to the canvas, charcoal-side down, with masking tape . Position the copy of the drawing where you want it on the canvas , with the art facing you and the charcoal touching the canvas, says Medford. [4] X Expert Source Kelly Medford Professional Artist Expert Interview. 26 March 2021. Place a square of masking tape in each corner and several squares along the edges to hold the paper in place. [5] X Research source The number of pieces of tape you need will depend on the size of the drawing. Placing one every 1 in (2.5 cm) or so will do the trick.

steps.title: Trace over the lines of the drawing with a ballpoint pen.
steps.content: Trace over the lines of the drawing with a ballpoint pen. Apply firm pressure as you go over the lines. This will transfer the charcoal to the canvas, recreating the lines of the drawing so it will be ready for you to paint, Medford explains. [6] X Expert Source Kelly Medford Professional Artist Expert Interview. 10 March 2021 Try to keep your hand off the drawing as you go over the lines as much as possible so you don’t rub any excess charcoal onto the canvas.

steps.title: Untape the drawing everywhere except for along the top and look under it.
steps.content: Untape the drawing everywhere except for along the top and look under it. Remove the tape carefully from the bottom corners, bottom edge, and sides. Gently lift up the paper by the bottom edge and peek under it to see if the drawing transferred all the way. [7] X Research source If you see any spots that didn’t transfer well or spots that you missed, re-tape the drawing and go over the lines with the ballpoint pen again.

steps.title: Remove the drawing when you are happy with the transfer.
steps.content: Remove the drawing when you are happy with the transfer. Untape the top corners and edge when all the traced charcoal lines are on the canvas. Discard the charcoal-covered copy of the drawing. [8] X Research source The transferred lines will be very delicate at this point, so be careful not to rub them with anything or you’ll smudge the charcoal.

steps.title: Fix the lines by tracing over them with an India ink pen.
steps.content: Fix the lines by tracing over them with an India ink pen. Use a fine-tipped India ink pen to trace over the transferred lines. This will fix and secure the outlines of your drawing so the canvas will be ready for paint. India ink is a black ink commonly used for drawing and outlining, especially for comics. You can get an India ink pen at an art supply store.

steps.title: Load an image into a projector.
steps.content: Load an image into a projector. Some projectors connect to a computer to project a digital image and some require you to load a hard copy into the projector. Load an image that you want to transfer according to the type of projector you have available. [9] X Research source The advantage of using a digital projector is you aren’t just limited to transferring your drawings to canvas. You can find any kind of digital image to use as a reference, such as a photo, and trace the outline onto the canvas to fill in with paint.

steps.title: Place your canvas in front of the projector.
steps.content: Place your canvas in front of the projector. Set up your canvas on an easel or another kind of stable stand. Place it about 5–10 ft (1.5–3.0 m) in front of the projector, depending how much space you have and how big you want the image to be. [10] X Research source You can adjust the distance between the canvas and the projector after you project the image to position it just right on the canvas.

steps.title: Turn out the lights and turn the projector on.
steps.content: Turn out the lights and turn the projector on. Make the room as dark as you can by turning off the lights and covering any windows or other sources of light. Turn on the projector to start projecting the image on the canvas. [11] X Research source Adjust the distance between the canvas and the projector if the image is really big or really small on the canvas. You can also make minor adjustments later using the projector’s zoom feature to get the size perfect. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Adjust the projector’s lens to focus the image on the canvas.
steps.content: Adjust the projector’s lens to focus the image on the canvas. Turn the ring around the lens back and forth to find the right focus for the image. Leave it when the lines are clear and sharp enough for you to trace. Make any final adjustments to the size of the image after it is in focus using the zoom feature on the projector.

steps.title: Trace the image onto the canvas with a pencil.
steps.content: Trace the image onto the canvas with a pencil. Use a pencil to trace all the lines you want to transfer to the canvas. Trace the entire image if you are using a drawing or trace the outline and specific features if you are using something like a photo. [13] X Research source You can go over the lines when you are done with a fine-tipped India ink pen if you want them to be darker and more defined.

steps.title: Print, sketch, or copy the original drawing.
steps.content: Print, sketch, or copy the original drawing. The process of transferring a drawing with transfer paper could smudge or tear your original art. Scan and print it on a new piece of paper, or use a copier to make a copy. You could also sketch a duplicate. [14] X Research source Make sure this copy is the size you want to transfer to your canvas.

steps.title: Place the transfer paper between the canvas and the copy.
steps.content: Place the transfer paper between the canvas and the copy. Position your transfer paper on the canvas exactly where your drawing will go. [15] X Research source Trim it if it’s too large for the canvas. Make sure the white or lighter side of the transfer paper is toward you, as the color on the other side will transfer onto the canvas, explains Leader. [16] X Expert Source Kathy Leader Artist Expert Interview. 13 February 2022. Place your drawing on top of the transfer paper.

steps.title: Secure the transfer paper and copy with masking tape.
steps.content: Secure the transfer paper and copy with masking tape. To prevent either sheet of paper from shifting as you trace your design, use strips of masking tape to secure them. Tape the transfer paper to the canvas and tape the copy of the drawing to the transfer paper.

steps.title: Use a ballpoint pen to trace your drawing.
steps.content: Use a ballpoint pen to trace your drawing. Press down firmly as you trace to ensure the lines transfer from the transfer paper onto the canvas. If you’re tracing a drawing, follow every line. If you’re tracing a detailed image, focus on the main outlines or silhouettes. You’ll be able to paint in the details after transferring. [17] X Research source Use a pen with visibly different ink from your drawing (either darker or a different color) so you can tell what you’ve already traced as you go.

steps.title: Carefully remove the copy and transfer paper.
steps.content: Carefully remove the copy and transfer paper. Peel away the tape slowly so you don’t damage the canvas. Before you remove the top strips of tape from the transfer paper, lift it up and peek to see if the transfer was successful. If not, re-tape and re-trace with more pressure until your transfer to canvas is complete.
